revision.text:
The '''Société de Linguistique de Paris''' (established 1864) is the editing body of the [[Bulletin de la Société de Linguistique de Paris|''BSL'']] (''Bulletin de la Société de Linguistique'') [[Academic journal|journal]] on [[linguistics]], which contains the proceedings of the society's seven yearly discussion sessions.
Each January, the group holds a study day dedicated to a particular topic. In 1997, it organised the ''Congrès International des Linguistes'' in Paris.
==External links== *http://www.slp-paris.com/
{{DEFAULTSORT:Societe de Linguistique de Paris}} [[Category:Linguistics journals]] [[Category:French-language journals]] [[Category:Publications established in 1864]]
{{ling-org-stub}}

{{Infobox short story | <!-- See [[Wikipedia:WikiProject Novels]] or [[Wikipedia:WikiProject Books]] --> | name = The Gnarly Man | title_orig = | translator = | image = [[File:The Gnarly Man.jpg|200px]] | caption = [[Edd Cartier]]'s illustration of the story in ''Unknown'', June, 1939 | author = [[L. Sprague de Camp]] | country = United States | language = English | series = | genre = [[Science fiction]] | published_in = ''[[Unknown (magazine)|Unknown]]'' | publisher = [[Street & Smith]] | media_type = Print ([[Magazine]]) | pub_date = June, [[1939 in literature|1939]] | english_pub_date = | preceded_by = | followed_by = }} '''"The Gnarly Man"''' is a [[science fiction]] story by American writer [[L. Sprague de Camp]], about an apparently immortal [[Neanderthal]] Man surviving into the present day.
==Publication history== The story was first published in the magazine ''[[Unknown (magazine)|Unknown]]'' for June, 1939 and first appeared in book form in de Camp's collection ''[[The Wheels of If and Other Science Fiction]]'' ([[Shasta Publishers|Shasta]], 1948).<ref name="laughlin">Laughlin, Charlotte, and Levack, Daniel J. H. ''De Camp: An L. Sprague de Camp Bibliography''. San Francisco, Underwood/Miller, 1983, pages 168-169.</ref><ref name="ISFDb">{{isfdb title|id=52284|title=The Gnarly Man}}</ref> It later appeared in the subsequent de Camp collections ''[[The Best of L. Sprague de Camp]]'' ([[Doubleday (publisher)|Doubleday]], 1978), ''[[Aristotle and the Gun and Other Stories]]'' (Five Star, 2002), and ''[[Years in the Making: the Time-Travel Stories of L. Sprague de Camp]]'' ([[NESFA Press]], 2005).<ref name="laughlin"/><ref name="ISFDb"/>
The story has also appeared in the magazines ''[[Fantastic Story Magazine]]'' for July, 1953 and ''[[Jim Baen's Universe]]'' for April, 2007, and the anthologies ''[[Human?]]'' (Lion Books, 1954), ''[[The Unknown (1963 anthology)|The Unknown]]'' ([[Jove Books|Pyramid Books]], 1963), ''[[The Freak Show (anthology)|The Freak Show]]'' ([[Rapp & Whiting]], 1970), ''[[Isaac Asimov Presents The Great SF Stories 1 (1939)|The Great Science Fiction Stories Volume 1, 1939]]'' ([[DAW Books]], 1979), ''[[Dawn of Time]]'' ([[Elsevier|Elsevier/Nelson Books]], 1979), ''[[Isaac Asimov Presents The Golden Years of Science Fiction: 36 Stories and Novellas|Isaac Asimov Presents The Golden Years of Science Fiction]]'' (Bonanza Books, 1983), ''[[Neanderthals (anthology)|Neanderthals]]'' ([[New American Library|Signet/NEL]], 1987), ''[[Unknown Worlds: Tales from Beyond]]'' ([[Galahad Books]], 1988), ''[[Modern Classics of Fantasy]]'' ([[St. Martin's Press]], 1997), and ''[[My Favorite Fantasy Story]]'' ([[DAW Books]], 2000).<ref name="laughlin"/><ref name="ISFDb"/> The story has been translated into [[Dutch language|Dutch]],<ref name="laughlin"/> [[French language|French]],<ref name="laughlin"/><ref name="ISFDb"/> [[German language|German]]<ref name="laughlin"/> and [[Italian language|Italian]].<ref name="ISFDb"/>
==Plot summary== Visiting a freak show, scientist Dr. Matilda Sandler takes an interest in the ape-man "Ungo-Bungo", who appears to exhibit genuine atavistic features. After the show she goes backstage and meets the man behind the role to ask if he will agree to be examined for scientific purposes. Ungo-Bungo, who calls himself Clarence Aloysius Gaffney, proves affable but reticent about his past and reluctant to submit to examination. In time, however, he warily consents in return for surgery to correct some old injuries.
Eventually it comes out that Gaffney is actually Shining Hawk, a Neanderthal Man over 50,000 years old, whose aging process was frozen early in life when he was struck by lightning. He had survived by his wits on the periphery of human society since the extinction of his own kind, using a succession of false identities and getting by as a blacksmith or in menial professions like his present one. He has been a witness to much of history from the margins, making little personal impact on it—though it is suggested that he may have been the original basis for the tales of the divine lame blacksmith [[Vulcan (mythology)|Vulcan]] (his leg injury is very old).
As it happens, however, Gaffney's caution proves well-founded; not only does Sandler develop an unwelcome crush on him, but the revelation of his secret brings out the worst in some of the scientists to whom it is confided. Discovering that the surgeon who is to perform his operation secretly intends to dissect him, Gaffney skips out. Later, from an undisclosed location, he sends his apologies and regrets to those who have befriended and aided him.
==Reception== According to [[Sam Moskowitz]], the story "broke ground for an entirely new approach on the treatment of such material,"<ref name="Moskowitz1">Moskowitz, Sam. "L. Sprague de Camp: Sword and Satire," in ''[[Amazing Stories]]'', v. 38, no. 2, February 1964, p. 100.</ref><ref name="Moskowitz2">Moskowitz, Sam. ''[[Seekers of Tomorrow|Seekers of Tomorrow: Masters of Modern Science Fiction]]'' (New York : [[Ballantine Books]], 1967), p. 160.</ref> which was "most notably emulated by [[Philip José Farmer]] in '[[The Alley Man]]'."<ref name="Moskowitz2"/>
[[Don D'Ammassa]] wrote "[t]he forthrightly sentimental "The Gnarly Man" is one of the most moving portraits ever to appear in the [science fiction] field."<ref>D'Ammassa, Don. "de Camp, L. Sprague" in ''[[Twentieth-Century Science-Fiction Writers]]'', Third Edition, Noelle Watson, Paul E. Schellinger, eds. (Chicago: [[Gale (publisher)|St. James Press]], c1991), p. 192.</ref>
More recently, Robert Wilfred Franson called the work "a good specimen of the distinct category of stories about Neanderthal Man in science fiction (or fantasy if you prefer)." He notes it "is a humorous story, but it may make you think even while you're enjoying it," and observes that "[d]e Camp obviously has fun here thinking through the likely practical concerns of someone living so long." He rates "[t]he character of Clarence [as] very well sketched in the space of a novelet," going on to say "[h]e brings to my mind a comparison with the title character, a speaking gorilla, in [[Daniel Quinn]]'s novel ''[[Ishmael (novel)|Ishmael]]''. The advantage is all Clarence's, as he is a man; whereas poor Ishmael is an ideological mouthpiece."<ref>Franson, Robert Wilfred. "[http://www.troynovant.com/Franson/DeCamp/Gnarly-Man.html The Gnarly Man by L. Sprague de Camp]" (review) on troynovant.com, Dec. 2008.</ref>
==Relation to other works== De Camp wrote that he got the subject for the story from his friend [[P. Schuyler Miller]], who was also writing a story about a Neanderthal man in modern times. The Miller piece, "Old Man Mulligan," appeared in the December, 1940 issue of ''[[Analog Science Fiction and Fact|Astounding Science-Fiction]]''. De Camp noted that the two stories were completely different, and used the incident to illustrate the principle that two science fiction writers, using the same idea, will write different stories, so there is nothing wrong with copying someone else's idea.<ref>De Camp, L. Sprague. ''[[Science-Fiction Handbook]]'', New York : Hermitage House, 1953.</ref><ref>De Camp, L. Sprague. "On The Gnarly Man and Old Man Mulligan." In ''Amra'', v. 2, no. 15, May 1961, pp. 21-22.</ref>
De Camp also featured Neanderthals in his later fantasy novel ''[[The Pixilated Peeress]]'' (1991). In the parallel world of that novel the species forms a relict population pushed by humanity into the higher elevations of the Alps. The fugitive hero Thorolf Zigramson takes refuge among a tribe of these "trolls," as they are known, and is adopted into their society and aided by them.
==Importance== "The Gnarly Man" is one of de Camp's most notable works.<ref>[http://www.locusmag.com/2000/News/News11a.html "Locus Online News: L. Sprague de Camp, 1907 - 2000"]</ref> The story's popularity has been demonstrated by frequent reprinting and anthologization.
==Notes== {{reflist}}
{{L. Sprague de Camp}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Gnarly Man, The}} [[Category:Science fiction short stories]] [[Category:Short stories by L. Sprague de Camp]] [[Category:1939 short stories]] [[Category:Works originally published in Unknown (magazine)]] [[Category:Neanderthals in fiction]] [[Category:Prehistoric people in popular culture]]

{{Use British (Oxford) English|date=December 2010}} {{Use dmy dates|date=December 2010}} {{Infobox book | | name = The History of The Hobbit | image = The History of The Hobbit.jpg | caption = | author = [[J. R. R. Tolkien]] & [[John D. Rateliff]] | editor = [[John D. Rateliff]] | cover_artist = J. R. R. Tolkien | illustrator = J. R. R. Tolkien | country = | language = English | series = ''The History of The Hobbit'' | genre = [[High fantasy]], [[children's literature]] | publisher = [[HarperCollins]] (UK)
[[Houghton Mifflin]] (USA) | release_date = 2007 | media_type = Print | pages = 905 (paperback) | isbn = 978-0-00-726646-3|isbn_note=(Mr. Baggins)
{{ISBN|978-0-00-726647-0}} (Return to Bag-End)
{{ISBN|978-0-00-736966-9}} (single volume e-book edition) | preceded_by = | followed_by = }} '''''The History of The Hobbit''''' is a two-volume study of [[J. R. R. Tolkien]]’s ''[[The Hobbit]]''. It was published by [[HarperCollins]] in May and June 2007 in the United Kingdom, with both volumes released in the United States by [[Houghton Mifflin]] on 21 September 2007; a boxed set combining ''The Hobbit'' with ''The History of'' The Hobbit was released on 26 October 2007. A single volume edition was released on 27 October 2011. The two-volume work contains Tolkien’s unpublished drafts of the novel, with commentary by John D. Rateliff.{{cite web | url = http://www.forodrim.org/arda/tbchron.html | title = A chronological bibliography of the writings of J.R.R. Tolkien | date = 1 September 2002 | origyear = 16 March 1996 | first = Åke | last = Bertenstam }} It also details Tolkien’s various revisions to ''The Hobbit'', including abandoned revisions for the unpublished third edition of the work, intended for 1960, as well as previously unpublished original maps and illustrations drawn by Tolkien himself.{{cite press release | url = http://www.tolkienlibrary.com/press/historyofthehobbit2.htm | title = History of the Hobbit: An essential resource book for the forthcoming movie adaptation of The Hobbit | date = 13 October 2006 | publisher = Tolkien Library }} ==Publication history== ''The History of'' The Hobbit: ''Volume I: Mr. Baggins''. This contains the first half of Tolkien’s draft material for ''The Hobbit'', along with commentary. It was published in the UK on 4 May 2007. ''The History of'' The Hobbit: ''Volume II: Return to Bag-End'', contains the last half of Tolkien’s original manuscript draft, with commentary and later drafts and appendices. It volume was published in the UK on 18 June 2007. ==Relationship to ''The History of Middle-earth''== When [[Christopher Tolkien]] began publishing ''[[The History of Middle-earth]]'', a twelve-volume series documenting J. R. R. Tolkien’s creative writing process in the creation of [[Middle-earth]], with texts dating from the 1910s to the 1990s, he made a conscious decision not to issue a volume detailing the creation of ''The Hobbit''. According to him, ''The Hobbit'' was not originally a part of the Middle-earth universe and was attached to his father's earlier, far darker [[legendarium]] only superficially, although the existence of ''The Hobbit'' forever altered the legendarium. As Christopher Tolkien was not going to embark on a published study of ''The Hobbit'', the task was given to Taum Santoski in the 1980s. Santoski had connections to the [[Marquette University|Marquette]] collection of Tolkien material, which is where the original manuscripts reside. He died in 1991, and ultimately the task passed to John Rateliff. Although Christopher Tolkien did not work directly on ''The History of The Hobbit'', the work is in a very similar vein to the "literary archaeology" of his ''History of Middle-earth''.{{cite web | url = http://www.tolkienlibrary.com/booksbytolkien/historyofme/description.htm | title = Books by J.R.R.Tolkien - The History of Middle-earth | work = Tolkien Library }} Rateliff submitted a finished draft of the book to Christopher Tolkien, who, approving of the work, gave ''The History of The Hobbit'' his personal blessing to be published in association with his father’s other works. ==See also== {{Portal|Middle-earth}} *[[Hobbit]] *''[[The Lord of the Rings]]'' ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20071223031625/http://www.tolkien-online.com/history-of-the-hobbit.html In-depth overview of both volumes of ''The History of The Hobbit''] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20081230005727/http://radio.nationalreview.com/betweenthecovers/post/?q=M2EyNjkyYjY4ODE1YzM2MTZhNjQxNTA3NzM1NmU5MmE= Audio interview with John D. Rateliff] {{J. R. R. Tolkien}} {{Middle-earth}} {{hobbit}} {{DEFAULTSORT:History Of The Hobbit}} [[Category:Books about Middle-earth]] [[Category:The Hobbit]] [[Category:2007 books]] [[Category:Books published posthumously]] [[Category:HarperCollins books]]

revision.text:
{{about|the linguistic and stylistic term|the psychological term|Logorrhea (psychology)}} '''Verbosity''' or '''verboseness''' is speech or writing that uses more words than necessary (for example, using "Despite the fact that" instead of "Although"). The opposite of verbosity is [[plain language]]. Some teachers, including the author of ''[[The Elements of Style]]'', warn writers not to be verbose. Similarly, some authors, including [[Mark Twain]] and [[Ernest Hemingway]], are known for their avoidance of verbosity. Synonyms for verbosity include '''wordiness''', '''verbiage''', '''prolixity''', '''grandiloquence''', '''garrulousness''', '''expatiation''', '''logorrhea''', and '''sesquipedalianism'''. Examples of verbosity are common in political speech, academic prose, and other genres. ==Etymology and synonyms== The word ''verbosity'' comes from [[Latin language|Latin]] ''verbosus'', "wordy". There are many other English words that also refer to the use of excessive words. ''Prolixity'' comes from Latin ''prolixus'', "extended". ''Prolixity'' can also be used to refer to the length of a [[monologue]] or speech, especially a formal address such as a lawyer's [[oral argument]].{{cite book |title=The Percy Anecdotes |last=Percy |first=Sholto |authorlink= Joseph Clinton Robertson |author2=Reuben Percy |year=1826 |publisher=T. Boys |location=London |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=SzJEAAAAIAAJ |page=9 }} ''Grandiloquence'' is complex speech or writing judged to be pompous or bombastic [[diction]]. It is a combination of the Latin words ''grandis'' ("great") and ''loqui'' ("to speak").{{cite web|url=http://dictionary.reference.com/browse/grandiloquence |title=Dictionary.com - Grandiloquence |publisher=Dictionary.reference.com|accessdate=2013-01-21}} ''Logorrhea'' or ''logorrhoea'' (from [[Greek language|Greek]] λογόρροια, ''logorrhoia'', "[[word]]-[[flux]]") is an excessive flow of words. It is often used [[pejorative]]ly to describe prose that is hard to understand because it is needlessly complicated or uses excessive jargon. The term is also sometimes applied to unnecessarily wordy speech in general.{{citation needed|date=January 2014}} ''Sesquipedalianism'' is a linguistic style that involves the use of long words. Roman poet [[Horace]] coined the phrase ''sesquipedalia verba'' in his [[Ars Poetica (Horace)|Ars Poetica]].{{cite web |url=http://www.perseus.tufts.edu/hopper/text?doc=Perseus%3Atext%3A1999.02.0064%3Acard%3D73 |title=Ars Poetica, l.97 |publisher=[[Perseus Project]] |accessdate=2 February 2011}} It is a [[Compound (linguistics)|compound]] of ''sesqui'', "one and a half", and ''pes'', "[[Foot (prosody)|foot]]", a reference to [[Meter (poetry)|meter]]. The earliest recorded usage in English of ''sesquipedalian'' is in 1656, and of ''sesquipedalianism'', 1863.{{cite book |last = Simpson |first =J. A. |last2=Weiner |first2=E. S. C. |title=The Oxford English Dictionary (Second Edition) |year=1989 |publisher=[[Oxford University Press]]}} ''Garrulous'' comes from Latin ''garrulus'', "talkative", a form of the verb ''garrīre'', "to chatter". The adjective may describe a person who is excessively talkative, especially about trivial matters, or a speech that is excessively wordy or diffuse{{cite web|url=http://dictionary.reference.com/browse/garrulous |title=Dictionary.com - Garrulous |publisher=Dictionary.reference.com|accessdate=2013-01-23}} The noun ''expatiation'' and the verb ''expatiate'' come from Latin ''expatiātus'', past participle from ''spatiārī'', "to wander". They refer to enlarging a discourse, text, or description.{{cite web|url=http://dictionary.reference.com/browse/expatiation |title=Dictionary.com - expatiation |publisher=Dictionary.reference.com|accessdate=2013-01-23}} ==Scientific jargon== The word ''logorrhea'' is often used [[pejorative]]ly to describe highly [[figurative language|abstract]] prose that contains little [[Literal and figurative language|concrete language]]. Since abstract writing is hard to visualize, it often seems confusing or excessive. Works in academic fields that involve many abstract ideas, such as [[philosophy]], often fail to include extensive concrete examples of their ideas. In an attempt to prove that "logorrhea" accompanies a lack of academic rigor, physics professor [[Alan Sokal]] wrote a nonsensical essay, and had it published in a respected journal (''[[Social Text]]'') as a [[practical joke]]. The journal defended the article as genuine even after Sokal denounced his own article publicly. The episode has come to be known as the [[Sokal Affair]].[http://www.physics.nyu.edu/faculty/sokal/ The Sokal Affair] The term is sometimes also applied to unnecessarily wordy speech in general; this is more usually referred to as ''prolixity''. Some people defend the use of additional words as [[idiom]]atic, a matter of artistic preference, or helpful in explaining complex ideas or messages.{{Citation needed|date=October 2014}} ==Examples== [[Warren G. Harding]], the 29th [[President of the United States]], was notably verbose even in his era. {{citation needed|date=December 2012}} A Democratic leader, [[William Gibbs McAdoo]], described Harding's speeches as "an army of pompous phrases moving across the landscape in search of an idea."{{cite web|url=http://www.whitehouse.gov/about/presidents/warrenharding|title=Warren G. Harding|publisher=The White House|accessdate=2013-01-23|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120726020027/http://www.whitehouse.gov/about/presidents/warrenharding|archive-date=2012-07-26|dead-url=yes|df=}} [[United States Senate|Senator]] [[Robert C. Byrd]] (Democrat, of [[West Virginia]]) lost his position as [[Majority Leader]] in 1989 because his colleagues felt his speeches, which often employed obscure [[allusion]]s to [[ancient Rome]] and [[Ancient Greece|Greece]], were not an asset to the [[Party politics|party base]].{{cite web|url=https://www.usatoday.com/news/washington/2005-05-22-byrd-fight-GOP_x.htm |title=At 87, Byrd Faces Re-election Battle of His Career |date=2005-05-22|accessdate=2014-01-23}} The ''[[Michigan Law Review]]'' published a 229-page parody of postmodern writing titled "Pomobabble: Postmodern Newspeak and Constitutional 'Meaning' for the Uninitiated". The article consists of complicated and context-sensitive self-referencing narratives. The text is peppered with number of parenthetical citations and asides, which is supposed to mock the cluttered style of postmodern writing.{{cite journal|last=Arrow|first=Dennis W.|title=Pomobabble: Postmodern Newspeak and Constitutional "Meaning" for the Uninitiated|journal=Michigan Law Review|date=December 1997|volume=96|issue=3|pages=461–690|jstor=1290146|doi=10.2307/1290146}} In ''[[The King's English]]'', Fowler gives a passage from ''[[The Times]]'' as an example of verbosity: "''The Emperor'' received yesterday and to-day General Baron von Beck.... It may therefore be assumed with some confidence that the terms of a feasible solution are maturing themselves in ''His Majesty's'' mind and may form the basis of further negotiations with Hungarian party leaders when ''the Monarch'' goes again to Budapest."{{cite book|last1=Fowler|first1=Henry Watson|last2=Fowler|first2=Francis George|title=The King's English|year=1908|publisher=Clarendon Press}} Fowler objected to this passage because ''The Emperor'', ''His Majesty'', and ''the Monarch'' all refer to the same person: "the effect", he pointed out in ''Modern English Usage'', "is to set readers wondering what the significance of the change is, only to conclude that there is none." ==Style advice== {{POV-section|talk=POV Issues|date=March 2014}} While verbosity may be rhetorically useful{{cite web |url=http://www.roanestate.edu/owl/clutter.html |title=Removing Word Clutter |work=Roane State}} verbose parts in communications are sometimes referred to as "fluff" or "fuzz".{{cite book |chapter=Simplicity |title=On writing well: An informal guide to writing nonfiction |location=New York |publisher=Harper & Row|author=[[William Zinsser]] |url=http://cgiss.boisestate.edu/~billc/Writing/zinsser.html}} The ancient Greek philosopher [[Callimachus]] is quoted as saying "Big book, big evil" (μέγα βιβλίον μέγα κακόν, ''mega biblion, mega kakon''), rejecting the [[Epic poetry|epic]] style of [[poetry]] in favor of his own. [[William Strunk]], an American professor of English advised in 1918 to "Use the active voice: Put statements in positive form; Omit needless words."{{cite book|last=Strunk|first=William|title=The Elements of Style|year=1918|publisher=Feedbooks|location=Paris}} In ''[[A Dictionary of Modern English Usage]]'' (1926) [[Henry Watson Fowler]] says, "It is the second-rate writers, those intent rather on expressing themselves prettily than on conveying their meaning clearly, & still more those whose notions of style are based on a few misleading rules of thumb, that are chiefly open to the allurements of [[elegant variation]]," Fowler's term for the over-use of [[synonym]]s.{{cite book|last=Fowler|first=Henry Watson|title=A Dictionary of Modern English Usage|year=1994|publisher=Wordsworth Editions|isbn=978-1-85326-318-7|origyear=1926}} Contrary to Fowler's criticism of several words being used to name the same thing in English [[prose]], in some other languages, including [[French language|French]], it might be thought to be a good writing style.{{cite book |title=Translation And Creativity: Perspectives on Creative Writing And Translation Studies |chapter=Painting with words |editor=Eugenia Loffredo, Manuela Perteghella |first=Ann |last=Paterson |year=2006 |isbn=0-8264-8793-9 |page=88 |publisher=[[Continuum International Publishing Group|Continuum]]|quote=. . . the rule of ''elegant variation'' (that is, using synonyms wherever possible), which purists consider to be essential for good style in French.}}{{cite book |title=The Translator's Handbook: (with special reference to conference translation from French and Spanish) |first=Frederick |last=Fuller |year=1984 |isbn=0-271-00368-5 |page=35 |publisher=[[Penn State University Press]] |quote=''Elegant variation'' French tends to avoid repetition of proper names, with a description of the person, at second reference.}} [[Mark Twain]] (1835–1910) wrote "generally, the fewer the words that fully communicate or evoke the intended ideas and feelings, the more effective the communication."{{cite web|url=http://www.search.com/reference/Prolixity |title=Reference for Prolixity |publisher=Search.com |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110716025741/http://www.search.com/reference/Prolixity |archivedate=July 16, 2011 }} [[Ernest Hemingway]] (1899–1961), the 1954 [[Nobel Prize|Nobel laureate]] for literature, defended his concise style against a charge by [[William Faulkner]] that he "had never been known to use a word that might send the reader to the dictionary."{{cite book| last1= Rovit|first1=Earl|last2=Waldhorn|first2=Arthur|title=Hemingway and Faulkner in Their Time|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=9zRLAq6eBS4C&pg=PA162|accessdate=28 February 2011|year=2006|publisher=Continuum|isbn=978-0-8264-1825-8|page=162}} Hemingway responded by saying, "Poor [[William Faulkner|Faulkner]]. Does he really think big emotions come from big words? He thinks I don't know the ten-dollar words. I know them all right. But there are older and simpler and better words, and those are the ones I use."{{cite book |last= Shapiro| first= Fred R.|title= The Yale Book of Quotations| url= https://books.google.com/books?id=ck6bXqt5shkC&pg=PA354 |accessdate= 28 February 2011| year= 2006 |publisher= Yale University Press| isbn=0-300-10798-6|page=354}} An inquiry into the [[7 July 2005 London bombings|2005 London bombings]] found that verbosity can be dangerous if used by emergency services. It can lead to delay that could cost lives.{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/terrorism-in-the-uk/8374581/77-inquests-emergency-services-should-use-plain-English.html |title=7/7 inquests: emergency services should use plain English|publisher=Telegraph|accessdate=11 March 2011}} A 2005 study from the [[psychology]] department of [[Princeton University]] found that using long and obscure words does not make people seem more intelligent. Dr. Daniel M. Oppenheimer did research which showed that students rated short, concise texts as being written by the most intelligent authors. But those who used long words or complex [[font]] types were seen as less intelligent.{{cite journal|last=Oppenheimer|first=Daniel M.|url=http://www.psych.utoronto.ca/users/psy3001/files/simple%20writing.pdf|format=PDF|year=2005|title=Consequences of Erudite Vernacular Utilized Irrespective of Necessity: Problems with using long words needlessly|journal=Applied Cognitive Psychology|volume=20|pages=139–15|doi=10.1002/acp.1178}} In [[William Shakespeare]]'s play ''[[Hamlet]]'', one of [[Polonius]]'s many [[sententiae|sententious]] maxims reads {{quote|Therefore, since brevity is the soul of wit,
And tediousness the limbs and outward flourishes,
I will be brief.}} Shakespeare's audiences were not necessarily inclined to read Polonius as someone who is perfectly wise; his sentences, like that of much early modern drama, can easily be seen as part of a comic trope.{{citation needed|date=January 2014}} [[George Orwell]] mocked logorrhea in "[[Politics and the English Language]]" (1946) by taking verse (9:11) from the book of [[Ecclesiastes]] in the [[Bible]]
"I returned and saw under the sun, that the race is not to the swift, nor the battle to the strong, neither yet bread to the wise, nor yet riches to men of understanding, nor yet favour to men of skill; but time and chance happeneth to them all."
and rewriting it as
"Objective consideration of contemporary phenomena compels the conclusion that success or failure in competitive activities exhibits no tendency to be commensurate with innate capacity, but that a considerable element of the unpredictable must invariably be taken into account."
Quantum physicist [[Richard Feynman]] has also spoken out against verbosity in scientific writing. {{cite book |last=Feynman |first=Richard |date=Nov 1, 1992 |title=Surely you're joking, Mr. Feynman |publisher=Vintage Random House |page=9 |isbn= |accessdate=Jan 5, 2015 |quote='his almost compulsive need to solve puzzles, his provocative mischievousness, his indignant impatience with pretension and hypocrisy, and his talent for one-upping anybody who tries to one-up him'}}{{cite speech|title=My friend Richard Feynman |first=Leonard |last=Susskind |event=TED Talks |location=Caltech |date=January 2011 |access-date=5 Jan 2015|url=http://www.ted.com/talks/leonard_susskind_my_friend_richard_feynman?language=en |quote=What Feynman hated worse than anything else was intellectual pretense -- phoniness, false sophistication, jargon }} ==See also== {{div col|colwidth=22em}} * [[Bloviation]], a style of empty, pompous political speech * [[Bullshit bingo]] * ''[[Cantinflear]]'' * [[Demagoguery]] * [[Gift of the gab]] * [[Glittering generality]] * [[Gobbledygook]] * [[List of Germanic and Latinate equivalents in English]] * [[List of plain English words and phrases]] * [[Loaded language]] * [[Logorrhea (psychology)]] * [[Nominalization]] * ''[[Nonscience]]'' (book) * [[Obfuscation]] * [[Pleonasm]] * [[Readability]] * [[Redundancy (linguistics)|Redundancy]] * [[Sokal affair]] * [[Tachylalia]] * [[Tautology (rhetoric)]] {{div col end}} ==References== {{Wiktionary|verbose}} {{Reflist|30em}} [[Category:Grammar]] [[Category:Linguistics]] [[Category:Rhetoric]] [[Category:Semantics]] [[Category:Language varieties and styles]] [[Category:Writing]]

{{Infobox bibliography | Author = [[William Faulkner]] | Image = William Faulkner 1954 (2) (photo by Carl van Vechten).jpg | ImageSize = 200px | Caption = Faulkner photographed in December 1954 by [[Carl Van Vechten]]. | Alt = | Novel = 19 | NovelLink = Novels | Story = 125 | StoryLink = Short stories | Play = 1 | PlayLink = Plays | 1Option = 20 | 1OptionName = Screenplays | 1OptionLink = Screenplays | 1OptionColor = #7fffd4 | References = Yes | RefLink = References }} The '''bibliography of [[William Faulkner]]''', an American writer, includes 19 novels, 125 short stories (not including stories that appear exclusively in novels), 20 screenplays (including uncredited rewrites), one play, six collections of poetry as well as assorted letters and essays. Faulkner made his debut as a published writer at the age of 21 with the [[poem]] "L'Après-midi d'un Faune", which appeared in ''[[The New Republic]]'' on August 6, 1919. Two more poems, "Cathay" and "Sapphics" and a short story, "[[Landing in Luck]]", were published in ''Mississippian'' in November 1919.{{sfn|Fargnoli|Golay|Hamblin|2008|p=461}} Faulkner's first novel, ''[[Soldiers' Pay]]'', was published in 1926 and his 19th and final, ''[[The Reivers]]'', in 1962, the year he died. Numerous works have been published posthumously. ==Fiction== ===Novels=== {| class="wikitable sortable" align="center" |- !width="150"|Title !width="120"|Publication date !width="150"|Publisher !Notes |- |''[[Soldiers' Pay]]'' |February 25, 1926 |[[Boni & Liveright]] |Faulkner's debut novel.{{sfn|Fargnoli|Golay|Hamblin|2008|p=483}} |- |''[[Mosquitoes (Novel)|Mosquitoes]]'' |April 30, 1927 |Boni & Liveright |{{sfn|Fargnoli|Golay|Hamblin|2008|p=483}} |- |''[[Sartoris]]'' |January 31, 1929 |[[Harcourt (publisher)|Harcourt, Brace]] |First novel set in the fictional [[Yoknapatawpha County]]; an abridged version of ''[[Flags in the Dust]]''. The original manuscript was published posthumously by [[Random House]] on August 22, 1973.{{cite web |title=WFotW ~ Flags in the Dust: COMMENTARY |url=http://www.mcsr.olemiss.edu/~egjbp/faulkner/n-fitd.html |last=Padgett |first=John B. |publisher=[[The University of Mississippi]] |year=2000 |accessdate=2011-06-21}} |- |''[[The Sound and the Fury]]'' |October 7, 1929 |[[Jonathan Cape]] & Harrison Smith |An appendix to the novel, "Compson 1699-1945", was included in ''The Portable Faulkner'', edited by [[Malcolm Cowley]] and published by [[Viking Press]] in 1946.{{sfn|Fargnoli|Golay|Hamblin|2008|p=483}}{{cite web |title=WFotW ~ The Portable Faulkner (Short Story Collections) |url=http://www.mcsr.olemiss.edu/~egjbp/faulkner/r_ssb-pf.html |last=Padgett |first=John B. |work=William Faulkner on the Web |publisher=The University of Mississippi |year=2000 |accessdate=2011-06-21}} |- |''[[As I Lay Dying (novel)|As I Lay Dying]]'' |October 6, 1930 |Jonathan Cape & Harrison Smith |{{sfn|Fargnoli|Golay|Hamblin|2008|p=483}} |- |''[[Sanctuary (Faulkner novel)|Sanctuary]]'' |February 9, 1931 |Jonathan Cape & Harrison Smith |An introduction to the novel by Faulkner was first included in the [[Modern Library]] edition of the novel published on March 25, 1932.{{sfn|Fargnoli|Golay|Hamblin|2008|p=468}}{{cite web |title=WFotW ~ Sanctuary: COMMENTARY |url=http://www.mcsr.olemiss.edu/~egjbp/faulkner/n-sanc.html |last=Padgett |first=John B. |work=William Faulkner on the Web |publisher=The University of Mississippi |year=2000 |accessdate=2011-06-21}} |- |''[[Light in August]]'' |October 6, 1932 |Harrison Smith & Robert Haas |A Foreword to the novel by novelist [[C.E. Morgan]] has been included in the [[Modern Library]] edition of the novel published in April 2012 | |- |''[[Pylon (novel)|Pylon]]'' |March 25, 1935 |Harrison Smith & Robert Haas |First novel since ''Mosquitoes'' not to be set in Yoknapatawpha County.{{sfn|Fargnoli|Golay|Hamblin|2008|p=483}} |- |''[[Absalom, Absalom!]]'' |October 26, 1936 |Random House |A Foreword to the novel by author [[John Jeremiah Sullivan]] has been included in the [[Modern Library]] edition of the novel published in April 2012 |{{sfn|Fargnoli|Golay|Hamblin|2008|p=470}} |- |''[[The Unvanquished]]'' |February 15, 1938 |Random House |A collection of seven interrelated short stories, six of which are revisions of stories previously published in ''[[The Saturday Evening Post]]''. "An Odor of Verbena" is new to ''The Unvanquished''.{{sfn|Fargnoli|Golay|Hamblin|2008|p=471}}{{cite web |title=WFotW ~ The Unvanquished: COMMENTARY |url=http://www.mcsr.olemiss.edu/~egjbp/faulkner/n-unvn.html |last=Padgett |first=John B. |work=William Faulkner on the Web |publisher=The University of Mississippi |year=2000 |accessdate=2011-06-21}} |- |''[[If I Forget Thee, Jerusalem|The Wild Palms]]'' |January 19, 1939 |Random House |Not set in Yoknapatawpha County. Consists of two interwoven stories: "The Wild Palms" and "Old Man". Included as ''[[If I Forget Thee, Jerusalem]]'', Faulkner's original title, in the [[Library of America]] collection ''Novels 1936-1940'', published in 1990. Sometimes published as ''The Wild Palms [If I Forget Thee, Jerusalem]''.{{sfn|Fargnoli|Golay|Hamblin|2008|p=471}} |- |''[[The Hamlet]]'' |April 1, 1940 |Random House |The first book in Faulkner's [[Snopes trilogy]].{{sfn|Fargnoli|Golay|Hamblin|2008|p=471}} |- |''[[Go Down, Moses (short story collection)|Go Down, Moses]]'' |May 11, 1942 |Random House |Contains seven interrelated short stories, five of which had been published previously. "Was" and "The Fire and the Hearth" are exclusive to the novel. Title changed to ''[[Go Down, Moses]]'', Faulkner's intended title, for subsequent editions.{{sfn|Fargnoli|Golay|Hamblin|2008|p=472}} |- |''[[Intruder in the Dust]]'' |September 27, 1948 |Random House |{{cite web |title=WFotW ~ Intruder in the Dust: COMMENTARY |url=http://www.mcsr.olemiss.edu/~egjbp/faulkner/n-iitd.html |last=Padgett |first=John B. |work=William Faulkner on the Web |publisher=The University of Mississippi |year=2000 |accessdate=2011-06-21}} |- |''[[Requiem for a Nun]]'' |September 27, 1951 |Random House |Sequel to ''Sanctuary''. Written as a [[play (theater)|play]] with prose parts preceding each act.{{sfn|Fargnoli|Golay|Hamblin|2008|p=474}} |- |''[[A Fable (novel)|A Fable]]'' |August 2, 1954 |Random House |Not set in Yoknapatawpha County. Winner of the [[Pulitzer Prize for Fiction]] and the [[National Book Award]] in 1955.{{sfn|Fargnoli|Golay|Hamblin|2008|p=475}}{{cite web |title=WFotW ~ A Fable: COMMENTARY |url=http://www.mcsr.olemiss.edu/~egjbp/faulkner/n-fabl.html |last=Padgett |first=John B. |work=William Faulkner on the Web |publisher=The University of Mississippi |year=2000 |accessdate=2011-06-21}} |- |''[[The Town (Faulkner)|The Town]]'' |May 1, 1957 |Random House |The second book in Faulkner's Snopes trilogy.{{cite web |title=WFotW ~ The Town: COMMENTARY |url=http://www.mcsr.olemiss.edu/~egjbp/faulkner/n-town.html |last=Padgett |first=John B. |work=William Faulkner on the Web |publisher=The University of Mississippi |year=2000 |accessdate=2011-06-21}} |- |''[[The Mansion (novel)|The Mansion]]'' |November 13, 1959 |Random House |The third book in Faulkner's Snopes trilogy.{{sfn|Fargnoli|Golay|Hamblin|2008|p=478}} |- |''[[The Reivers]]'' |June 4, 1962 |Random House |Winner of the Pulitzer Prize for Fiction in 1963.{{sfn|Fargnoli|Golay|Hamblin|2008|p=478}}{{cite web |title=WFotW ~ The Reivers: COMMENTARY |url=http://www.mcsr.olemiss.edu/~egjbp/faulkner/n-reiv.html |last=Padgett |first=John B. |work=William Faulkner on the Web |publisher=The University of Mississippi |year=2000 |accessdate=2011-06-21}} |- |} ====Library of America editions==== To date, [[Library of America]] has published all of Faulkner's novels in five volumes, containing restored authoritative texts. * ''Novels 1926–1929'', containing ''[[Soldiers' Pay]]'', ''[[Mosquitoes (novel)|Mosquitoes]]'', ''[[Flags in the Dust]]'', ''[[The Sound and the Fury]]'' ({{ISBN|978-1931082891}}, 1170 pages, published April 6, 2006) * ''Novels 1930–1935'', containing ''[[As I Lay Dying (novel)|As I Lay Dying]]'', ''[[Sanctuary (Faulkner novel)|Sanctuary]]'', ''[[Light in August]]'', ''[[Pylon (novel)|Pylon]]'' ({{ISBN|978-0940450264}}, 1056 pages, published December 1, 1985) * ''Novels 1936–1940'', containing ''[[Absalom, Absalom!]]'', ''[[The Unvanquished]]'', ''[[If I Forget Thee, Jerusalem]]'', ''[[The Hamlet]]'' ({{ISBN|978-0940450554}}, 1148 pages, published June 1, 1990) * ''Novels 1942–1954'', containing ''[[Go Down, Moses]]'', ''[[Intruder in the Dust]]'', ''[[Requiem for a Nun]]'', ''[[A Fable (novel)|A Fable]]'' ({{ISBN|978-0940450851}}, 1110 pages, published October 1, 1994) * ''Novels 1957–1962'', containing ''[[The Town (Faulkner)|The Town]]'', ''[[The Mansion (novel)|The Mansion]]'', (1967) *"Al Jackson" (1971) *"And Now What's To Do" (1973) *"Nympholepsy" (1973) *"The Priest" (1976) *"Mayday" (1977) *"Frankie and Johnny" (1978) *"Don Giovanni" (1979) *"Peter" (1979) *"A Portrait of Elmer" (1979) *"Adolescence" (1979) *"Snow" (1979) *"Moonlight" (1979) *"With Caution and Dispatch" (1979) *"Hog Pawn" (1979) *"A Dangerous Man" (1979) *"A Return" (1979) *"The Big Shot" (1979) *"Once Aboard the Lugger (II)" (1979) *"Dull Tale" (1979) *"Evangeline" (1979) *"Love" (1988) *"Christmas Tree" (1995) *"Rose of Lebanon" (1995) *"Lucas Beauchamp" (1999) {{Col-end}} ===Plays=== *''Marionettes'' (one-act play, first produced at the [[University of Mississippi]] on March 4, 1921{{cite web |title=WFotW ~ Works by William Faulkner (comprehensive list) |url=http://www.mcsr.olemiss.edu/~egjbp/faulkner/lib_ps.html#drama |last=Padgett |first=John B. |work=William Faulkner on the Web |publisher=The University of Mississippi |year=2000 |accessdate=2011-06-21}}) *''[[Requiem for a Nun]]'' ===Screenplays=== ====Produced==== {| class="wikitable sortable" align="center" |- !Year !Film{{sfn|Fargnoli|Golay|Hamblin|2008|p=494–95}} !Credit type !Collaborator(s) !Based on |- |1933 |''[[Today We Live]]'' |[[WGA screenwriting credit system|Dialogue]] |Edith Fitzgerald {{small|(screenplay)}}

Included in ''Faulkner's MGM Screenplays''. |- |1932 |''The College Widow'' |Treatment for unwritten screenplay |Based on ''Night Bird''. Included in ''Faulkner's MGM Screenplays''. |- |1932 |''Absolution'' |Treatment for unwritten screenplay |rowspan="3"|Included in ''Faulkner's MGM Screenplays''. |- |1932 |''Flying in the Mail'' |Treatment for unwritten screenplay |- |1933 |''War Birds'' |Screenplay |- |1933 |''Louisiana Lou'' |Screenplay |Used for the 1934 film ''Lazy River'' without Faulkner's involvement. |- |1942 |''The De Gaulle Story'' |Screenplay |Appears in ''Faulkner: A Comprehensive Guide to the Brodsky Collection, Volume III: The De Gaulle Story'', published in January 1984 by [[University Press of Mississippi]]. |- |1943 |''Country Lawyer'' |Story treatment |Included in ''Country Lawyer and Other Stories for the Screen'', published in June 1987 by University Press of Mississippi. |- |1943 |''Battle Cry'' |Screenplay |Appears in ''Faulkner: A Comprehensive Guide to the Brodsky Collection, Volume IV: Battle Cry'', published in December 1985 by University Press of Mississippi. |- |1945 |''Stallion Road'' |Screenplay |Appears in ''Stallion Road: A Screenplay'', published in December 1989 by University Press of Mississippi. |- |} ==Poetry collections== *''Vision in Spring'' (1921){{cite web |title=WFotW ~ Works by William Faulkner (comprehensive list) |url=http://www.mcsr.olemiss.edu/~egjbp/faulkner/lib_ps.html#poetry |last=Padgett |first=John B. |work=William Faulkner on the Web |publisher=The University of Mississippi |year=2000 |accessdate=2011-06-21}} *''The Marble Faun and A Green Bough'' (1924) *''Helen, a Courtship and Mississippi Poems'' (1981) ==References== {{reflist|2}} ===Bibliography=== {{refbegin}} *{{cite book |title=Critical Companion to William Faulkner: A Literary Reference to His Life And Work |series=Critical Companion |last1=Fargnoli |first1=A. Nicholas |last2=Golay |first2=Michael |authorlink2=Michael Golay |last3=Hamblin |first3=Robert W. |year=2008 |publisher=[[Facts on File]] |location=[[New York City]] |isbn=978-0-8160-6432-8 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=dQca8cin24gC |ref=harv}} {{refend}} *{{cite book |title=Faulkner's People: A complete guide and index to the characters and fiction of William Faulkner |series= |last1=Kirk |first1=Robert W. |last2=Klotz |first2=Marvin |authorlink2= |last3= |first3= |year=1965 |publisher=University of California Press |location= [[Los Angeles]] |isbn= |url= |ref=harv}} {{refend}} {{William Faulkner}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Faulkner, William, Bibliography}} [[Category:Bibliographies by writer]] [[Category:Bibliographies of American writers]] [[Category:Poetry bibliographies]] [[Category:Works by William Faulkner| ]]
